comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From this interesting page on Cashel Railway: Most of these services were hauled by a team engine called locomotive No. 74, which was one of the '47' Class designed at Inchicare. Built in 1887 it was typical of the tank locos which worked many GS & WR branches around the turn of the century. Loco 74 was to serve the Cashel branch line far most of its history. It was replaced by a steam railcar, which seated six first-class and forty-eight third-class but it did not provide for extra passengers when necessary and was transferred to the Drumcondra Link Line. After its departure Cashel trains were usually worked by small 0-4-4Ts or by the ubiquitous standard 0-6-0.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: I was going to comment on the fact that No. 74 is listed as a tank engine when there seems to be a tender down the track a little, beside what looks to be a hand cranked water pump, but then I've just read the following from Niall McAuley's link about the Cashel Railway. Why wasn't the line a success? Perhaps the obvious reason was that there were never enough people travelling on it and the volume of goods was never satisfactory. A second problem was a troublesome water' supply. Although there was a permanent water tank at the station an old engine tender and a hand-operated pump were also provided to ease the situation. Also from that same site... The final chapter of the Cashel Branch Line story was written in 1959-60 when the tracks and bridges were removed. This operation cost more than the original laying of the line. Some years later Cashel station was sold to a Dutch textile company and converted into a factory.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
My Flickr feed seemed to have missed this wonderful photo! 
You can't beat Cashel station as being one of the most appropriate of all 'Irish' railway locations, with the dramatic backdrop of the Rock . The railway was terribly late reaching Cashel and by this time the grand Victorian era had come to end - the buildings at Cashel were of corrugated iron construction and the platforms finished off in bare concrete. It must have been captured more or less after it opened judging by the freshness of the track and ballast, as well as the top soil on the embankment (Jan 1905). 
Regrettably the angle captured can't be recreated because of the mentioned factory built on the station site!
